newsitem.title: UK: Gilts biggest loser in mixed week - Salomon.
newsitem.headline: Gilts biggest loser in mixed week - Salomon.

text.p: Bond markets were mixed in the latest week with Britain chalking up the biggest losses and Canada climbing the most, according to data from Salomon Brothers.
British gilts dropped 0.91 percent in the week in local currency terms amid lower-than-expected M4 money supply data. The market was also tracking losses in Bunds.

Canadian bonds gained 0.65 percent in the week, boosted by foreign buying and tame Canadian economic data and a rally as U.S. interest rates remained unchanged after Tuesday's Federal Open Market Committee meeting.
The Salomon Brothers World Government Bond Index lost 0.22 percent in local terms for the week ended May 21.
Other losers in the week in local currency terms were France, Germany and the Netherlands.
German Bunds fell 0.58 percent, while French debt lost 0.60 percent and Dutch bonds dropped 0.65 percent, dragged lower by losses in Germany and general weakness in the European markets.

The other top gainer of the week was Australia with a climb of 0.52 percent. Italian BTPs and Spanish Bonos swam against the European tide to notch up gains of 0.31 and 0.16 respectively in local terms.
For dollar-based investors the pattern was broadly similar, with Japan the only market showing a strikingly different picture in dollar terms compared to local currency.
JGBs clocked up considerable gains of 3.35 percent in dollar terms against a loss of 0.22 percent in yen.
U.S Treasuries offered returns of 0.11 percent.

Salomon's bond index is calculated using all government bonds with over one year to maturity, weighted for market capitalisation. Only bonds freely available to institutional investors and with a certain minimum amount outstanding are included. Returns take account of price moves and accrued interest.
